Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of functional/structural constraints operating on the Drosophila genome
Award.AbstractNarration:
Chromosomes, the cellular entities that carry genes, can suffer modifications in their structure due to breakages and reattachments in new configurations. These breakages do not occur at random: some chromosome regions are prone to participate in chromosomal rearrangements while others are seldom affected. The reasons for these differences in susceptibility among chromosome regions are unclear. The current notion is that genes that work cooperatively or that have common molecular requirements are clustered in particular chromosome regions. It is thought that the viability and/or fertility of the organism can be impaired if these regions are disrupted by rearrangements. In humans, multiple diseases correlate with rearrangements of particular chromosome regions. Interestingly, those chromosome regions are intact in healthy individuals, an observation that also applies to other vertebrate species. This grant funds the first rigorous experimental test to understand the consequences of disrupting these delicate, ultra-conserved genomic regions. The work will use the fruit fly Drosophila, which is one of the best model organisms to understand the consequences of chromosomal rearrangements. Drosophila chromosomes possess the same kind of delicate, ultra-conserved regions as vertebrates do. In addition, Drosophila researchers have molecular tools to induce precise chromosomal rearrangements and to subsequently monitor their effects on the organism. The principal investigator plans to disrupt these special chromosome regions of Drosophila in order to analyze the consequences.

The research is likely to have implications for understanding human genetic diseases. Furthermore, this grant will train undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows in advanced concepts of genetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The experiments performed under this award have revealed important aspects about how the way genes are organized on chromosomes is reshaped over evolutionary time.  This is important because it provides clues as to why, for example, particular regions of the human genome, upon reorganization by gross mutations, elicit particular human diseases. Specifically, our main goal was to test the consequences for the organism of perturbing experimentally regions of the chromosomes that have maintained an unusually high degree of conservation across species, i.e. they show an apparent refractoriness to be disrupted. A high degree of conservation suggests that important functions of the organisms might be impaired upon disruption and reorganization. For our experiments, we used fruit flies given the multiple tools that can be used to manipulate them at the genetic level. Contrary to conventional wisdom, we found very subtle effects and not a significant harm, which suggests that the mechanisms that make regions to be conserved are quite complex. This does not mean that no fitness consequences will be observed when highly conserved regions of the genomes are disrupted. Additional perturbation are required to have a more solid view. Further, we explored how the organization of the chromosomes in the nucleus can affect some very interesting patterns that researchers have found in the last decade. We have found that regions that are in contact with the inner nucleus in somatic cells tend to be more conserved across species and that they can accommodate a larger than expected number of genes moving from one region to another of the genome. Lastly, we silenced a gene that is present in a single species but not in the rest in order to see whether a newly evolved gene can be important for the organism. Specifically, we tested the relevance of a gene presumably involved in male fertility using fruit flies. We found that even very young genes can play very important roles for the organism, which is relevant to understand how species become adapted to changing environmental conditions.

At the level of training, this award has been instrumental for exposing 12 students and 2 postdoctoral fellows to both advanced and traditional experimental techniques in genetic and genomics as well as for consolidating their skills in quantitative data analysis. Members of underrepresented groups have been preferentially benefited by the research activities developed. Also, the 2 postdoctoral fellows have honed different kinds of skills in order to become successful mentors either in Academia or in other disciplines. Further, we have generated multiple datasets that have been submitted to public repositories, facilitating the analysis of these data by other colleagues. Importantly, our work underscores the need of a cross talk between different procedures (experimental and purely computational) in order to tackle unsolved questions in Biology. Lastly, the research activity of this award has generated some materials that can be integrated by the PI in his teaching duties.
